Description: Rim and body sherd of probably East Dorian pottery cup with low, everted rim and sharply carinated profile; wholly glazed, perhaps with added red banding on inside; inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: The fabric of this sherd is the same as other East Dorian cups with everted rims. For parallels, see British Museum 1886,0401.96, which which was analysed with NAA by H. Mommsen (Bonn) (see Schlotzhauer and Villing 2006: 55, Table 1; Sample NAUK 51). Analysis of the fabric placed it in Group EMEB with a place of production in the region of the Knidian peninsula and recent excavations in the Sanctuary of Apollo at Emecik on the Knidian peninsula have also produced several examples of these types of cups (Attula 2005, 144, pl. 78, 297-9). For parallels regarding the slip and shape, see Attula 2006, 144, nos 299-300 from the sanctuary of Apollo at Emecik. Also published by Johnston, 2014, 107, no. 2, fig. 11. R. Attula, Keramik, in D. Berges (Ed.) 'Knidos: Beiträge zur Geschichte der archaischen Stadt'. 101-153. Johnston, A.W. 2014. ‘Naukratis, Aegina and Laconia; some individuals and pottery distribution’, in A. Tsingarida (ed.) Pottery Markets in the Ancient Greek World. Proceedings of the International Symposium held at the Université libre de Bruxelles. Bruxelles. 103-12.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXIII, no. 258)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 664, no. 219)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p.257, no.5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GM.10) (phase 3)
